Award.AwardTitle: NSF/DOE Thermoelectrics Partnership: An integrated approach towards efficient, scalable, and low cost thermoelectric waste heat recovery devices for vehicles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1048708

Huxtable

This project involves researchers at the Center for Energy Harvesting Materials and Systems at Virginia Tech and their industrial partner, Romny Scientific. The investigators seek to develop and use novel fabrication techniques to enable high volume production of thermoelectric materials. In addition, the project will advance novel heat sink and interface designs with the goal to maximize the efficiency of conversion of waste heat to electric power in vehicle applications.

Intellectual Merit: New automated aerosol deposition techniques to rapidly synthesize skutterudites and silicides will be developed. In addition, nanocomposites of these, and other, compositions will be formulated, based on isostatic pressing technology. Thermal management and heat sink design will involve augmentation methods such as use of minichannels and swirling flow jet impingement to maximize temperature differences across the thermoelectric material and, in turn, maximize the conversion efficiency. Interface resistances will be minimized through analysis and measurement of the effective properties with attention focused on the relationship between the interface behavior and the processing and fabrication techniques. Advanced metrology including, but not limited to, diffraction and spectroscopic techniques, temperature-dependent X-ray diffraction, in-situ environmental high resolution scanning electron microscopy, and high resolution transmission electron microscopy will be used to both (i) determine thermoelectric material properties and (ii) measure the performance of thermoelectric modules in full scale experiments.

Broader Impact: The project seeks to develop new thermoelectric materials and module designs to ultimately improve fuel economy and reduce emissions in vehicle applications. Undergraduate and graduate students will be involved in the research and will be given opportunities for internships with the industrial partner, Romny Scientific, and the Naval Undersea Warfare Center. The research will be integrated into coursework including an existing graduate course with a specific focus on energy harvesting. The prototype modules will be demonstrated in full scale vehicle applications for outreach purposes. Outreach to middle- and high school students and teachers, local industry and small businesses, and several local HBCUs will also be conducted as will incorporation of the research in an annual energy harvesting workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A significant amount of the chemical energy input to a vehicle in the form of fuel is ultimately wasted as heat in the exhaust gases expelled from the vehicle. Capturing even a modest fraction of this wasted energy would translate into tremendous savings in fossil fuel usage as well as a reduction in vehicle emissions. Thermoelectric (TE) devices that can directly convert the thermal energy lost in the hot exhaust gases into useful electrical power offer a possible method for partial recovery of this wasted energy. However, thermoelectric materials and devices suffer from several drawbacks including low efficiency, high cost, challenges in manufacturability at the large volumes needed for automobiles, and durability to withstand rugged use on vehicles. In this project, we addressed several of this issues, and our work primarily focused on (1) thermoelectric materials, (2) heat exchangers and thermal management, (3) interfaces, and (4) metrology.

With regards to materials, our team examined a range of systems, but our work emphasized materials that could be synthesized with scalable techniques such that one could produce large quantities of efficient, yet low cost, materials. Highlights of our work included the development of a chemical synthesis process for producing zinc oxide (ZnO) materials with improved thermoelectric properties. We found that the inclusion of nanoscale aluminum precipitates formed through a vacuum sintering processes could reduce thermal conductivity by a factor of about seven, while still maintaining promising electrical and thermoelectric properties. With a separate material system, we also developed a new mechanical alloying method for mixing the raw elements for magnesium silicide (MgSi) based alloys. This alloying process was rapid, repeatable, gave high yield, and is scalable to high volume production. The MgSi materials had reasonable thermoelectric efficiency and were low cost, thus they were a factor of approximately 20 better in terms of the dimensionless thermoelectric figure of merit (ZT) per dollar than commonly used lead telluride (PbTe) materials. These MgSi materials have already attracted interest from Tier 1 automotive suppliers.

In order to create efficient thermoelectric systems, one must also effectively move heat to and from the devices in addition to improving the actual thermoelectric materials. Thus, we have also designed and evaluated a variety of heat exchangers through computations and experiments for both the hot and cold sides of the thermoelectric devices. Our work showed that impinging jets of liquid coolant provided excellent heat transfer (e.g. 10-20 °C lower temperatures compared to a baseline case with guided coolant flow) with limited pressure drop (less than two psi) for cold side heat exchangers. On the hot side, where we need to effectively remove heat from the hot exhaust gases, we demonstrated that short pin-fins with length less than 15% of the exhaust channel height could increase heat transfer rates by a factor of two. In addition to the pin-fins, we also examined a variety of other extended surface features, and found that significant improvements in heat transfer could be achieved with longitudinal vortex generator (LVG) structures. Through the use of system level models that were validated with prior work in the literature, we found that the LVGs could increase the heat input to a thermoelectric generator by approximately 50% when compared with smooth surfaces.

In terms of the broader impacts of our work, the societal benefits of low-cost, lightweight, and efficient thermoelectric generators on automobiles are far-reaching as improved fuel performance and reduced emissions would have a worldwide impact on the economy and the environment.
